source_heading: Cinemaya: The Asian Film Quarterly, Vol. 59, no. 1 (Summer 2003)
title: Okinawa: In Japan and Out of It. [Article]
creator: Yomota, Inuhiko
abstract: The Japanese islands of Okinawa have always had a distinct identity. For long, they suffered discrimination at the hands of the mainlanders; at other times, they were regarded as objects of anthropological interest, as evident in some of the films made by prominent filmmakers from the mainland. More recently, a handful of directors have tried to paint a more complex picture of an Okinawa which, "while structurally within Japan, is still really the other in terms of history, culture and language." Inuhiko Yomota speaks of how Japanese films and filmmakers have approached the question of singularity of Okinawa and Okinawans and about the films now being made by Okinawans themselves.

title: An Encounter with Tian Zhuangzhuang: Restraint & Freedom. [Interview]
creator: Wu, Cynthia
abstract: "Tian Zhuangzhuang is one of the most controversial figures of China's Fifth Generation filmmakers. He and his fellow classmates, such as Zhang Yimou adn Chen Kaige, are all graduates from the Beijing Film Academy. This group of talented filmmakers has embodied the New Wave in Chinese cinema since the 1980s. Using unconventional film techniques that shift away from traditional cinematic practices, they have succeeded in gaining international recognition for modern Chinese cinema.This is a film review by Shoma A. Chatterji of the 2003 Indian film Again in the Forest by Goutam Ghose."

source_heading: Cinemaya: The Asian Film Quarterly, Vol. 59, no. 1 (Summer 2003)
title: Sunrise in the East: Contemporary Bengali Cinema. [Article]
creator: Chatterji, Shoma A
abstract: "Of late, the long drought in Bengali Cinema seems to be over. Films, theatres, and the film market have received a face-lift. In many instances, however, it was at the cost of content and aesthetics. Now, in the past few years, have come a few films that have deftly negotiated the line between 'off-bet' and 'mainstream' - and succeeded with the public. Today, Bengali Cinema sports a new look, tries out new genres and is more cosmopolitan than before in content, production and distribution. Indeed, the bottomline of Sony Pictures Entertainment Films India is "Taking Bengal to the World.""

source_heading: Cinemaya: The Asian Film Quarterly, Vol. 59, no. 1 (Summer 2003)
title: 2002: The Year of Bollywood Blues. [Article]
creator: Srinivasan, Sidharth
abstract: "The year 2002 was the worst ever in the history of the Hindi film industry. The box-office was at an all time low, films registered a 95% rate of failure and distributors and exhibitors were hard hit. Producers, who generally managed to make a neat table profit, were also left high and dry. Then came Mystery, a low budget supernatural triller directed by Vikram Bhatt, produced by Mukesh Bhatt and written by the prolific Mahest Bhatt. The film starred relative newcomers to Bollywood, Biphasa Basu and Dino Morea, erstwhile models who were donning greasepaint for the first time. Mystery was an Indianized version of Robert Zemeckis' What Lies Beneath, and it generated over US$ 4 million of business from its modest US$ 1 million budget."

source_heading: Cinemaya: The Asian Film Quarterly, Vol. 59, no. 1 (Summer 2003)
title: A Mirror to Ray and Kurosawa. [Article]
creator: Banerjee, Utpal K
abstract: "In the 50s, two momentous events took place in the world of Asian cinema. In 1951, Akira Kurosawa from Japan won the Grand Prix at the Venice Film Festive (and, laster, the Oscar for Best Foriegn Film) for Rashomon, and virtually introduced Asian Cinema to the West. So great was his influence, that Rashomon has enterd common parlance as a term used to denote the relative nature of truth. In 1955, Satyajit Ray from India won the 'Best Human Document' award at Cannes (and, later the Selznick Award at Venice) for Pather Panchali. Even today, after many decades, the film still remains an uplifting experience."

title: News from Pakistan. [Film News]
creator: Gul, Aijaz
abstract: "Producers, distributors and exhibitors are under great stress after losing millions of repees at the box-office in the past three months. What with the cold spell, the rains, the World Cup Cricket and Muharram, cinemas nationwide have been put to sleep. Can the low-budget Hearless directed by Rashid Dogar with its vigorous songs brighten things up? The other recent release, Deceit, directed by Pervez Rana, is a vengence orgy and could meet (disastrous) fate of its predecessors."

title: Alamayer's Folly. [Film News]
creator: Keshvani, Nazir
abstract: "Havey Keitel is slated to play the title role in Malaysian director U-Wei Haji bin Saari's adaptation of Joseph Conrad's novel Alamayer's Folly. The film is called Kelemahan Alamayer. Keitel has signed a memo with Le Brocquy Fraser Productions, who will produce the film when the funding is finalised. The cast includes Christine Hakim, Kahlid Salley, Al Manik and Desmond Crowe, with Alain Choquar from France as cinematographer. The film has a budget of US$2.5 million and will be shot in Borneo. It is scheduled for production in early 2004."

title: New from Malaysia. [Film News]
creator: Muhammad, Amir
abstract: "A group of Malaysian filmmakers are in the process of setting up the Malaysian Independent Film Foundation to showcase and promote new work. The primary forces behind MIFF are the producer Lina Tan (creator of a long-running, occassionally controversial TV magazine show, "3R", aimed at empowering young women in areas such as sexuality), and James Lee, the most prolific of the Malaysian digital-video generation. Lina Tan herself is planning to take the plunge into independent features by the end of this year. She knows the time is right to galvanise the resources available, so that MIFF can serve as a one-stop centre for researchers, programmers and the general public."

title: Vendetta (1992) directed by Leung Siu Hung. [Film Review]
creator: Quinn, Brian
column20: Vendetta (1992) directed by Leung Siu Hung. [Film Review] by Quinn, Brian, pp. 17-18 (2 p) |
abstract: "After watching so many Hong Kong films in the last couple of years, I was starting to get a little burned out on the endless stream of gun-toting gangsters. flying swordsman. hopping vampires, and lovesick ghosts. A few weeks after watching many of these films I was finding it hard to differentiate between them. Luckily, everytime my interest has started to wane, a film comes along that totally blows me away and reminds me why I started seeking out these films in the first place. VENDETTA is just such a film, a solidly directed work that will keep you glued to the screen and on the edge of your seath throughout its lean eighy-six minute running time."

creator: Crawford, Travis
column20: Captured For Sex: An Indepth Review. [Film Review] by Crawford, Travis, pp. 28-30 (3 p) |
abstract: "Modern Japanese pornography is overwhelmingly sadistic, as anyone can find out by spending 5 minutes in any Japanese bookshop.
